issue.title: [ENH] turning `numba` into a soft dependency

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
I think we should turn `numba` into a soft dependency, since it is not core to the framework, but used only in specific estimators.

---

key arguments for:

* the only key change is giving users the choice `numba` yes/no
* for users with `numba` installed, the `sktime` experience remains precisely the same
  * users without `numba` will be able to use `sktime`, currently they cannot
  * users without `numba` will still be able to find `numba` based estimators using `all_estimators`, similar to other soft dependencies
* it should be easier to upgrade `sktime` to newer python or package versions, of core dependencies, as `numba` is slow to update compatibility
* makes python 3.11 compatibility possible, at current date
* architectural: reduces coupling, increases layer separation; minimize soft dependencies, see context below

key arguments against:

I don't really see any except the work required

---

Update: more context on architectural and usage benefits.

the general desideratum is "minimize dependencies". This is an explicit architectural north star of scikit-learn as well as sktime.

See e.g., this paper on sklearn design,
https://mblondel.org/publications/lbuitinck-ecmlpkdd2013.pdf
search for "dependencies" in the text.

In the past 6 months, we have made the interfaces of estimators much clearer, including that we can manage python versions and package dependencies on the estimator level, rather than at the sktime package level

This has prompted multiple lines of refactoring around "minimize dependencies":

* migrate sktime-dl into sktime because we can isolate tensorflow to estimators
* isolate `statsmodels`
* isolate `numba`
* newly added annotation module soft dependencies are fully isolated

`statsmodels` isolation and soft dep is very similar, see this PR: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3821

---

FAQ

> does this remove `numba` support from `sktime`?

No, `numba` will still be supported and used in estimators.
It will only change to be optional, for people who do not want (or need) to use estimators that depend on `numba`.

> will this impact performance of `sktime`?

No. For users who have `numba` installed, the experience is precisely the same. The logic of `numba` based estimators stays the same.

No change in estimator accuracy or speed. (evidence: look at the tests in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3843 which test for both)

The only change is that users get a choice whether they want `numba` or not.

> How can this be implemented within the estimators? Numba requires tags/decorators at each function to be compiled.

See https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3631

strategy is the same as any dependency isolation on estimator level and uses the `sktime` base class layer:

* move `numba` imports into functions and classes, where possible
* add the package dependency tag to `numba` dependent estimators to isolate them
* use `pytest.skipif` to conditionally skip `numba` dependent non-suite tests if `numba` is not installed
* specific to `numba` due to use of decorators: where loose functions are decorated with `jit` and `njit`, move them to a private module `_orig_modulename_numba`, and move imports of that into functions or classes

Same as isolating any soft dependency, see, e.g., same strategy for `statsmodels`:

https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3445
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3515
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3632
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3821

rename.from: [ENH] turning all non-core libraries into a soft dependency
rename.to: [ENH] minimizing dependencies - analyze whether current dependencies can be made softdeps

body:
@patrickzib, I think this is a valid issue.
I will not speculate about the intention, I just want to point out one policy that Wikipedia has

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Do_not_disrupt_Wikipedia_to_illustrate_a_point

and that we should also adopt for `sktime`.

Given concurrent discussion on internal channels, and your vehement opposition to turn `numba` into a soft dependency here: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3567
this could easily be seen as "disruption to make a point", but, as said, I do not want to speculate about intentions.

Having said that, I do think it is valid to check whether the argumentation holds for the other packages.

We should also include into consideration, since very relevant:
* `deprecated`
* `statsmodels`

The key point in the argument is "not core to the framework, but used only in specific estimators", and this requires some knowledge of current `sktime` architecture.

As I will explain, the premise you imply is not true from an architectural standpoint for all the dependencies - or, more precisely, true to a different degree, which causes certain dependencies to be more easy or difficult in this respect. As said, you need to understand for that how `sktime` is designed.

First some explanation, what does "core to the interface" mean?

It means you canotn easily separate or isolate the dependency, say, on the layer of estimators.

More specifically, it mostly means that it would break the base class interface if you were to remove the dependency - `BaseObject`, `BaseClassifier`, `BaseForecaster`, and the like.

Whereas, "not core to the interface" means, removal would break only specific estimators, but the rest of `sktime` continues working.

Noting here that we do not intend to *remove* anything, just turning it into a soft dependency, i.e., an option for users to have it yes/no.

What breaks if you remove it is just a proxy definition for "core to the interface". Base classes break -> core, cannot be easily isolated. Base classes do not break, only specific estimators break -> can probably be isolated.

Let's start with the "easy" ones:

* `statsmodels` - interfaced only in estimators. Can be isolated easily.

In fact, we *have* recently done that in four PR that follow simple isolation patterns and make use of base class tags that identify and tag dependent functionality that isolates the dependencies.

You can have a look at the description in the PRs this would work - goto https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3516 how and look into the linked PR for more details on what isolation patterns were used.

* `deprecated` - this one we could easily remove, but some deprecation messages might break. It does not break the framework though, so you could argue it is not strictly necessary. It is also not required in any estimators.

Therefore, I would actually be in favour of removing it altogether, and doing deprecation in a more manual way, i.e., with `warnings`.

"medium difficulty ones":

* `numba` is required in estimators only, so in principle it can be isolated the same way as `statsmodels`. The only problem are the decorators that cannot be wrapped in functions or classes, as it would interrupt the compilation chain. Therefore, an additional pattern for isolation needs to be introduce, isolation in files rather than just functions and classes. Except that, it works the same way as `statsmodels`, even if it is a bit more fiddly.

* `scipy` is mostly required in estimators only, and there is no decorator fudge, so those instances could be isolated like `statsmodels`. The problem is where `scipy` is used in base class defaults, for instance turning different probabilistic predictions into each other when one is implemented or not the other, or in hard-coded evaluation metrics. Further, there is also utility functionality such as in benchmarking/evaluation, which would drop out. Not saying that these cases couldn't be solved, there are only a few, but it would require extra design thinking for these special cases, not just applying rote patterns like in `numba` or `statsmodels`. Here's an experimental PR I made on this: https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3707

hard ones - but imo also worth thinking about!

* `sklearn` is truly all over the place in estimators, and not just there. Metrics, primitives, components, evaluation workflows, all kinds of things are interfaced. This could, however, in principle be solved, the interface locus is just a factor of 5-10 or so larger than `statsmodels` or `numba`. The other issue with `sklearn` is that our base class *inherits* from `sklearn`'s `BaseEstimator`, so the entire base class framework depends on `sklearn` - remove `sklearn`, and basically none of `sktime` works currently.
* However, the base class interface is also one of the key interface points where we *do* want to reduce coupling with sktime. The `skbase` project with @RNKuhns is intended to do exactly that: https://github.com/sktime/skbase - it is the major first step in decoupling `sklearn` from the base class framework, as more and more functionality in `sktime` has been supplanting `sklearn` base class functionality and the dependency has become less strong.
* it does need some understanding of `sktime` architecture though to understand how `skbase` is related to the "minimize dependencies" desideratum, so if you have any questions about that, @RNKuhns or I will be happy to help you answer.

* `pandas` is also a hard case, since the key data containers currently rely on it. However, the mtype system has a level of abstraction, and it is not inconceivable that with stricter decoupling and modularization of that you could make `sktime` completely flexible to the choice of datatype, e.g., entirely using `dask` or `polars`.
* There are ongoing efforts and design discussions in this direction, e.g., `dask` mtypes - https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3554 - or, the design discussion to move mtypes into classes which then could be used to isolate and manage dependencies introduced throigh data types, see https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3512, or https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/2337
* at the very end of this path, you could think about having mtypes being objects that manage and isolate dependencies via tags, just like the estimators. This would in theory allow to isolate `pandas` similar to how we can isolate `statsmodels` to estimators.
* imo these are technically complex discussions that may make sense only with a bit of software engineering experience, as well as architectural understanding of sktime, again I'm happy to explain. Other core devs who could probably explain, given earlier involvement in related topics, are @chrisholder, @lmmentel, @mloning, @RNKuhns, @miraep8.

To finish up with some points

* isolating soft dependencies is what has made, for instance, this possible:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7985502/205401393-7505415d-f4ab-4de6-8c99-f6af9bab4447.png)

many thanks to @christopherbunn  

if you need an explanation why soft dependency isolation is relevant here, happy to oblige. Or anyone involved in the `conda` upgrade!

* perhaps also to spell this out, there is no "vendetta" or "personal quest" against `numba` here, as has been implied in slack channels and the `numba` discussion.

I simply think reducing soft dependencies, isolating dependencies, minimizing dependencies and external coupling are just best practice in software engineering, coupling and cohesion are architecture 101 concepts and very useful to know about for anyone who would like to be a software architects and/or responsible for a package like `sktime`.

The "optimal state" is, in fact, no core dependencies at all, if they can be detached from the framework.

In the very long term, and I may be speculating, possibly everything except `sklearn` might be a soft dependency, i.e., in a state where we have full data layer abstraction and a robust multi-layer framework, possibly also a modular package infrastructure that we have been contemplating in the pipeline project with pywatts (FYI @benHeid, @smeisen, @kalebphipps)

This endstate would also be truly a "library framework", i.e., users can move estimator and data abstractions around, and the dependencies would be dynamically managed based on an abstract specification language - `sktime` is currently moving, and will hopefully be moving in that architectural direction.
